titleStmt.title: A list of his Majesties Navie Royall, and merchants ships their names, captaines and lievtenants, their men and burthens in every one, now setting forth for the guard of the narrow seas, and for Ireland this yeare, 1642. With an order, for the speedy rigging of the navie for the defence of the kingdome. Algernon Percy, Earle of Northumberland, Lord Percy, Lucy, Poynings, &c. Knight of the most noble order of the garter, and one of his Majesties most Honourable Privy Counsell, Lord high Admirall of England, and Lord Generall of his Majesties Navy Royall.

notesStmt.note: With a portrait of the Earl of Northumberland.
The order from Parliament is dated: Die Mercurii. 2. Martii. 1641. [i.e. 1642].
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: A Li≈øt of his Maje≈øties Navie Royall, and Merchants Ships, Their Names, Captaines and Lievtenants, their Men and Burthens in every one, now ≈øetting forth for the Guard of the narrow Seas, and for IRELAND this yeare, 1642.
With an Order, for the ≈øpeedy Rigging of the Navie for the Defence of the KINGDOME.

ALGERNON PERCY, Earle of Northumberland, Lord Percy, Lucy, Poynings, &c, Knight of the mo≈øt Noble Order of the Garter, and one of his Maje≈øties mo≈øt Honourable Privy Coun≈øell, Lord high Admirall of ENGLAND, and Lord Generall of his Maje≈øties Navy Royall.

figure.p: The right Honourable, and most noble, ALGERNON PERCY, Earle of Northumberland, Lord Poynings. Fitz-payne & Brian & Lat: kt: of the most noble. order of the Garter. Admirall & Generall of his Maiesties Fleet for this: Expedition Ao 1640
figure.byline: Sould by The: Penner at the Exe:

list.head: The Kings Maie≈øties Ships: the Names of Captains, and Lievtenants, Ships, Men, and Burthens.
list.item: 1. IN the Iames, Robert Earle of Warwick, Vice Admirall, Ma≈øter Slingsby Lievtenant, 260. men, burthen 875. tun.
2. In the Saint George William, Batten Captaine, Ma≈øter William Smith Lievtenant, 260. men, burthen 792. tunne.
3. In the Rainebow, Sir John Menns Captaine, Ma≈øter Lutton Lievtenant, 260. men, burthen 721. tunne.
4. In the Reformation, Sir David Murrey Captaine, Ma≈øter Stan≈øbuy Lievtenant, 260. men, burthen 731. tunne.
5. Victory, Captaine Fogge Captaine, Ma≈øter Fogge Lievtenant, 240. men, burthen 742. tun.
6. Henrietta Maria, Captaine Hatch Captaine, Ma≈øter Wattes Lievetenant, 250. men, burthen 793. tunne.
7. Unicorne Captaine Frenchfield Captaine, Ma≈øter Sommer≈øton Lievtenant, 250. men, burthen 767 tunne.
8. Charles Swanley Captaine, Ma≈øter Darey Lievtenant, 250. men, burthen 810. tun.
9. Vantgard, Captaine Blith Captaine, Mr. Blith Lievetenant, 250. men, burthen 751. tunne.
10. Entrance, Captaine Owen Captaine, Ma≈øter Bowen Lievtenant, 160. men, burthen 539. tun.
11. Garland, Captaine Sting≈øby Captaine, Ma≈øter Walters Lievetenant, 170. men, burthen 767.
12. Lion, Captaine Pri≈ø≈øe Captaine, Ma≈øter Hill Lievetenant, 170. men, 602 tunne.
13. Antelope, Captaine Burley Captaine, Ma≈øter Willeby Lievetenant, 160. men, burthen 512. tun.
14. Mary Ro≈øe, Captaine Fox Captaine, 100. men, burthen 321. tunne.
15. Expedition, Captaine Wake Captaine, 100. men, burthen 301. tunne.
16. Greyhound, Captaine VVheler Captaine, 50. men, burthen 126. tunne.

list.head: Merchants Ships.
list.item: 1. In the Martane, Captaine George Martane Captaine, Ma≈øter Hakriger Lievtenant, 210. men b. 700. tunne.
2. Sam≈øon, Captaine A≈øhly Captaines Ma≈øter Andrew Lievtenant, 180. men, bound 600. tunne.
3. Cae≈øar, Captaine Elias Iorden Captaine, Ma≈øter Norton Lievetenant, 180. men, b. 600. tunne.
4. London, Captaine Iohn Stephens Captaine, Ma≈øter Pomroy Lievetenant 180. men, b. 600. tunne.
5. Unicorne, Captaine Edward Iohn≈øon Captaine, 143. men, b. 475. tunne.

7. Bonny Venter, Captaine George Swanly Captaine, 120. men, b. 400. tunne.
8. The Pro≈øperous, Captaine VVilliam Driver Captaine, 120. men, b 400. tunne.
9. Hurclens, Captaine Mover Captaine, 150. men, b. 350. tun.
10. Paragon, Captaine Leonard Harris Captaine, 105. men, b. 350 tunne.
11. Hopefull Luke, Captaine Lee Captaine, 105. men, b. 350 tunne.
12. Golden Angell, Captaine Walker Captaine, 105. men, b. 350. tunne.
13. Exchange, Captaine Lucas Captaine, 89. men, b. 325. tunne.
14. Mayden-head, Captaine Lewton Captaine, 90. men, b. 300. tunne.
15. Providence, Captaine William Swandly Captaine, 81. men, b. 271. tunne.
16. Jocelyn, Captaine Partridge Captaine, 60. men, 200. tunne.

2. Bonny Venture, Captaine Henry Stradling, 160. men, 557. tunne.

list.head: Merchants Ships.
list.item: 1. Di≈øcovery, Captaine John Brok-haver, 144. men, 380. tunne.
2. Ruth, Captaine Robert Cun≈øtable, 120. men, 400. tunne.
3. Employment Captaine Tho: A≈øly, 132 men, 440. tunne.
4. Peter, Captaine Peter Stroung 81. men, 270. tunne.
5. Pennington, Captaine Io≈øeph, Iordan, 360. men, 135. tunne.
6. Fellow≈øhip, Captaine Thomas Colle, 87. men, 290. tunne.
7. Mary Captaine William Capell, 30. men, 103. tunne.
8. Iohn, Captaine John Thomas: 15. men. 50. tunne.

div.p: THE Lords and Commons in this pre≈øent Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, having received adverti≈øement of extraordinary preparations, made by the neighbouring Princes, both by Land and Sea: the Intentions whereof have beene ≈øo repre≈øented, as to rai≈øe an apprehen≈øion in both Hou≈øes, that the publicke Honour, Peace, and Safety of his Maje≈øtie, and his Kingdome cannot be ≈øecured, unle≈ø≈øe a timely cour≈øe be taken for the putting of this Kingdome into a condition of Defence, at Sea as well as Land. It is therefore ordered by the Lords and Commons afore≈øaid, that the Earle of Northumberland, Lord high Admirall of England, doe forthwith give effectuall direction, and Order, that all and every the Ships belonging to his Maje≈øties Navy, which are fit for ≈øervice, and not already abroad, nor de≈øigned for this Summers Fleet, be with all ≈øpeed rigged and put in ≈øuch a readine≈ø≈øe, as that they may be ≈øoone fitted for the Sea; and that his Lord≈øhip doe al≈øo make knowne unto all the Ma≈øters, and Owners of ≈øuch ≈øhips as now are in, or about any the Harbours of this Kingdome, and may be of u≈øe for the publicke defence thereof, that it will be an acceptable ≈øervice to the King, and Parliament. If they likewi≈øe will cau≈øe their Ships to be rigged, and ≈øo farre put in readine≈ø≈øe, as they may be at a ≈øhort warning ≈øet forth to Sea, upon any immergent occa≈øion, which will be a meanes of great ≈øecurity to his Maje≈øty, and his Dominions.

IT is ordered, that the Ma≈øters of the Merchants Ships, ≈øhall be alowed after the rate of ten ≈øhillings a moneth, to every one of his men for rigging of the Ships, and 21. ≈øhillings a moneth for every one of his men when they are at Sea, and to have one third part of the mony in hand and another part at foure moneths end and the la≈øt payment at ≈øixe moneths end, being the expiration of the time, for which they are impre≈øt, or when they come to Black-Wall. and to have their Colours and Surgions, Che≈øts furni≈øhed at the Kings charge, out of the Kings Store-hou≈øe, and pre≈ø≈øe-mony alowed them, but if any Ship chance to be ca≈øt away in the Kings ≈øervice, they are to have no allowance, but the Kings pay for ≈øixe moneths.
